reviewText: When else have I ever been able to write a review where both the words "clever" and "adorable" fit together?From my perspective as a parent: I just took three boys, ages 3, 7 and 8, to see Wallace and Grommit: the Curse of the Were-Rabbit.  They all had a great time with it, laughed  often and were completely absorbed by the story.  There was not one scary or inappropriate thing in this movie for kids.  Thumbs up!From my perspective as an adult:  Hilarious, clever, silly, and somehow adorable all at once, just what one would expect from a W&G; film but even better, if that's possible.  If you haven't been introduced to Nick Park's creations Wallace and Grommit (an uber-inventor and window washer by trade, with his all-too-human dog) before, I urge you to look up the other short movies on Dvd as soon as possible and spend the next few evenings with them.  I promise you that you will be surprised and delighted with the quirky Aardman universe, the sly parodies of cinematic clichés, and the perfect attention to little details that went into creating the claymation sets and figures.  This is surely the pinnacle of its art form, and a lot of fun for "kids of all ages" to boot.This new movie, Curse of the Were-Rabbit, continues in the world of W&G;, but with a new twist; the pair are now in the business of pest control with the very unique humane policy; they cannot dispose of the marauding garden pests that they capture in the usual manner because Wallace is too soft-hearted, so instead they keep them in cages at their home.  Of course this has become a growing problem since the business took off and has been very brisk lately...until Wallace hatches an ingenious plan to change the very nature of rabbitiness, from ravenous vegetable-munchers into...well, we aren't entirely sure.  It would seem that something went awry with the latest mind control gadget.  Now, there's some kind of giant rabbit monster on the loose and naturally the town is desperate to protect their prize-winning vegetables for the annual Harvest Faire.  Can Grommit solve the mystery of the monster's true nature before somebody decides to exact some not-so-humane pest control?Without a doubt, I am going to rush out and buy this one as soon as it's released on Dvd in order to complete my Nick Park collection.-Andrea, aka Merribelle
summary: Fun, timeless and innocent...but packed with great wit.

reviewText: If I had never seen any of Nick Parks' other work, this would be a revelation - full of heart, brilliant, & clever. However, I'm a long time fan and while I'd never pan any of his work, this isn't the best he's ever done. That honor would have to go to either "A Close Shave" (short subject) or "Chicken Run" (feature length).Although the bits & pieces are typically hilarious and inventive, the whole is somewhat less than the sum of its parts. And there are a few rough edges. The human villain and, to a lesser degree, Wallace's lady interest lack some of the qualities I've come to expect from Parks' work. Also the plot, while serviceable, isn't as crisp and coherent as some of his best work. Finally, both the animal villain and the cute secondary animals aren't up to the standards he set in "A Close Shave".In short, I can recommend it to anyone. But true Aardman fans shouldn't set their expectations as high as they might.
summary: Excellent, but Parks doesn't top himself

reviewText: If you are looking for a family friendly film that will amuse both toddler and adult, you need look no further than Nick Parks' latest clay animation entry "The Curse of the Were-Rabbit starring Wallace and Gromit." For the uninitiated, Wallace (the voice of Peter Sallis) is a sweet-natured and eccentric, cheese-loving inventor of Rube Goldberg contraptions of dubious merit and Gromit is his silent, trusty canine who functions more as a side-kick than a pet. When we first join them, the intrepid duo are running the cottage business of "Anti-Pesto," a neighborhood varmint removal service, specializing in the humane disposal of pesky vegetable-consuming rabbits. The annual Vegetable Competition is just around the corner and Anti-Pesto's clients are panic-stricken that their potential prize-winning beauties are at risk.When summoned by Lady Tottington (the voice of Helena Bonham Carter), the hostess of the annual competition, to her ancestral home to humanely handle her rabbit infestation problem ("It is after all in their bunny natures"), Wallace is both flattered and dazzled. Employing his patented Bun-Vac 6000, Wallace basically Hoovers the rabbits up into a glass containment chamber where the bunnies are suspended floating in a delightful mid-air freefall. By earning the gratitude of Lady Tottington, Wallace incurs the jealous wrath of Victor Quartermaine. Ralph Fiennes oozes wonderfully smarmy disdain as the voice of the upper-class twit, Quartermaine, the trigger-happy rival for the attentions of Lady Tottington.The film spoofs the 1930's Universal horror films with a "science gone horribly wrong" theme, when Wallace attempts to reprogram the rabbits using "the Mind-manipulation-o-matic," a choice which has consequences. What follows are moonlight transformations and a campy Frankenstein's monster send-up of angry farmers with pitchforks and torches.The look of this low-key English charmer is really quite detailed and beautiful, and there are many wonderfully droll touches throughout (such as a laser-eyed garden gnome security system). You need not have seen any of Nick Park's previous film shorts to fully enjoy this latest entry, but if you have - then you are more than likely part of his fan base. Highly recommended. "The Curse..." is cracking good fun.
summary: Wallace and Gromit's Newest Adventure
Title: N/A

reviewText: Prior to this film's opening, I always wondered why Wallace and Gromit weren't HUGE in America.Yeah, sure, they're pretty Brit, but then again so is Harry Potter and American Idol, and they do OK even if they don't have the charm and whimsy of Nick Park's claymation characters.Wallace is a hapless inventor who builds Rube Goldbergian dream machines that inevitably go haywire; Gromit is his quietly courageous dog who, inevitably, flies in to save the day.The movie opens with Wallace and Gromit running a pest control business, briskly protecting their village's vegetables from the buck teeth of hungry rabbits. When a mysterious, herbivorous creature appears and wreaks garden havoc, things get a little tricky.Park and co-director Steve Box can now give the movie a big-budget scale and sheen that the shorts don't have, but they retain their clay-dry humor and gleefully bad puns.As amiable as it is, though, "Were-Rabbit" isn't the bases-loaded pop fly home run it should've been. Earlier W&G; outings, "A Close Shave" and "The Wrong Trousers," are fat-free, tightly-plotted half hours; at 80 minutes, this new film sometimes feels sluggish and its big finale isn't nearly as eye-popping as the wrap-ups of "Shave" or "Trousers," which are like Indiana Jones films made with toys.That said, there's still a lot to like about it, including hordes of clay bunnies and the sight of Gromit's lovable mug up on the big screen, so newcomers to Wallace and Gromit may be charmed. If they are, they'll be happier to find that the duo's earlier adventures are even better.
summary: Wallace and Gromit stretch out on the big screen (3.5 stars)
Title: N/A

reviewText: That cheese-loving, dim-witted inventor Wallace and his long-suffering, resourceful mutt Gromit have made a great transition from 30 minute shorts to an 85 minute feature. It's one of the funniest, slyest and most innocent comedies around, and one of the most action-filled, too. Wallace and Gromit run a pest control business. People have hired them to catch all the bunnies that are chomping up their vegetables. This is vital because the annual veggie contest and fair given by Lady Tottingham is only days away. Through indescribable circumstances a bunny is turned into a giant were-rabbit and Wallace and Gromit are on the case. But then, in an amazing twist, the were-rabbit is...but you'd better see the movie.Believe me, while children will love the film, this is a movie, just as Chicken Run was, for adults of all ages. The inventions are so rococo they probably need to be seen twice to be really appreciated. Allusions to horror movies and their stars, from King Kong to Lon Chaney, Jr. to Ernest Thesiger, are scattered all over the place. The puns and visual gags fly fast and loose. In the Wensleydale-loving Wallace's library are just briefly seen copies of, among other fine books, East of Edam and Fromage to Eternity. When Wallace loses his clothes and has only a cardboard produce box to protect his modesty from Lady Tottingham, you have to be quick to catch a glimpse of a small warning label glued on the box, "May contain nuts." And when Lady Tottingham invites Wallace to her private garden and shows him her prize melons.... But don't frown; it's all smile-inducing innocence.Gromit may be silent, but everyone else speaks and the actors voicing the parts are exceptional. Peter Sallis, now 84, continues to be the voice of Wallace. Helena Bonham Carter does Lady Tottingham. Ralph Fiennes does Victor Quartermaine and is completely unexpected. Anyone who can only picture Fiennes as primarily a serious actor who isn't too funny, as I have, needs to see this movie. Quartermaine is an upper-class twit, loud, dense, eager to hunt down and blow away the were-rabbit and anything else. Fiennes really is funny and nails the character. If you didn't know it was him you'd swear the voice belonged to some awful caricature of upper-class British oafdom.This is a clever, funny movie.
summary: Clever, Sly, Innocent And Very Funny

reviewText: The Oscar winning shorts headlining inventor Wallace and his loyal dog Gromit are expanded to a feature film in Wallace and Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit.  The results are a splendidly entertaining 85 minutes of fun, excitement, comedy, and escapism that put most live-action films to shame.Wallace and his canine pal, Gromit, have a thriving business as Anti-Pestos who hunt down and capture rabbits that are eating the vegetable yards of the neighborhood.  Meanwhile, Wallace, who is constantly inventing new contraptions and devices, is experimenting with a mind altering machine that will brainwash a rabbit into not wanting veggies.  But of course an accident occurs and later, under the full moon, a strange series of attacks by a large, mysterious creature ravages the vegetable gardens of many a neighbor.  Meanwhile, Wallace is attracted to a woman, Lady Tottington, whose vegetables are part of the annual Great Vegetable Convention.  At the same time, a lecherous man named Victor Quartermaine is on the make for her riches.  As the vegetable competition is ready to begin, all the entrants are threatened by the giant veggie eating creature. Who is this strange creature and how can it be stopped?  It falls on the loyal, resourceful Gromit to try to save the day even as danger threatens Wallace and the vegetable gathering.Wallace and Gromit remind you of comedians Penn and Teller, where one is a straight man to the other's silent pantomimes.  Speaking of Gromit, his character clearly pays homage to the silent characters of Chaplin, Keaton, and even France's Monsieur Hulot.  Voice work by Ralph Fiennes (The Constant Gardener) and Helena Bonham Carter (The Corpse Bride) as Victor and Lady Tottington respectively is quite convincing.  Although the characters are made from claymation, they take on a life of their own, and pretty soon you forget that you are watching clay and instead care about the characters as if they were real people.Clever puns aside, and there are many of them that whiz by at a steady clip, the sight gags are delightfully amusing and inventive.  The humorous situations are never stale or run out of steam but are consistently inspired.  The title is a giveaway to the plot as it alludes to the werewolf mythology and the full moon.  The transformation that serves as a major plot point is played for laughs and not horrific, Wolfman inspired though it may be.  The identity of the creature is a playful parody of every werewolf movie ever made with a nod to such staples as King Kong and Frankenstein.  The filmmakers even throw a couple of red herrings to keep you guessing until the big revelation.  There are scary moments however, without needing to be graphic or terrifying.  All this is from a G-rated film?The pacing is very good and the mood goes from simple comedy to suspense to a hint of romance.  Not only is the animation effective with its expressive characters emoting believably, but the overall production is strong even in areas one might not expect in an animated film, namely the cinematography and editing.  Even the rousing musical score done by committee is heroically inventive and inspired.Made by the creative team (Directors Steve Box and Nick Park) which scored big on the recent Chicken Run, `Wallace and Gromit' soars even higher in terms of overall excellence.  It works for kids to be sure as the screen is filled with a smorgasbord of colorful and imaginative sets, characters, and effects.  What is special is how the film plays for adults in equal measure as the simple storyline is played straight and the jokes are rapid and clever.  A great deal of care and time (five years) went into making every scene work, no small feat.  This marks another high point this past year in animation as the art form has enjoyed a surge in popularity and creativity.  Not only is Wallace and Gromit one of the best animated films of the year (surely giving The Corpse Bride a run for its money), it's one of the best films of 2005.  So when is the sequel coming out?
summary: WALLACE AND GROMIT: THE CURSE OF THE WERE-RABBIT is superior family fun

reviewText: It's been a scant sixteen years since Nick Park introduced us to his intrepid characters - befuddled inventor Wallace and his stoic dog, Gromit, in the now comparatively primitive short, "A Grand Day Out". Yet, Park and his collaborators - Steve Box, who also co-directed, as well as Bob Baker and Mark Burton - continue to astound with their meticulous craftsmanship, expansive imagination, coherent and clever storytelling and mostly a genuine love for the characters and the eccentric world in which they live. Both "The Wrong Trousers" and "A Close Shave" had similar set-ups to this feature-length film with a nefarious villain lurking about and Gromit ingeniously commandeering a nick-of-time chase finale. The consistent structure is perhaps the only predictable element of this wonderful film.This time, Park and company tweak the notion of a werewolf movie with a gigantic rabbit that terrorizes an English village in its ravenous search for oversized vegetables. In the dark of night, it lays waste to the neighborhood gardens, and all the stock characters come out to theorize about its origins and next move, including a skeptical, test tube-headed policeman and a Sam Jaffe-like vicar who spouts all kinds of mumbo-jumbo about the beast within. Wallace and Gromit are now running a new business aptly named Anti-Pesto, based on yet another of Wallace's wacky machines, the Bun-Vac 6000, which literally sucks invasive rabbits out of their holes in a humane, cruelty-free way. They run an especially booming business in a community obsessed with the upcoming 517th Annual Giant Vegetable Competition.The contest sponsor and bestower of the prized Golden Carrot, Lady Campanula Tottington, is intent on using the services of Anti-Pesto to have the beast humanely removed before the competition. However, complicating matters is her caddish, toupee-challenged suitor, Victor Quartermaine, determined to destroy not only the rabbit but Wallace once his affections for Lady Tottington become known. The material is rich with smartly observed parody replete with cheeky references to "King Kong", "Jaws" and "Jurassic Park", as well as the Hammer horror pictures of the sixties and the Ealing comedies of the fifties. Peter Sallis' voice as Wallace is becoming as familiar as Mel Blanc's as Bugs Bunny, and his pixilated tone brings a welcome note of consistency to the production. He is joined by Ralph Fiennes, who has never been so animated as he is as Quartermaine, and Helena Bonham-Carter almost unrecognizably upper-crust as Lady Tottington.No Wallace and Gromit adventure would be complete without the creators' weakness for puns - cheese lover Wallace's library contains book titles such as "East of Edam", "Fromage to Eternity" and "Brie Encounter"; there's a jar of Middle Age Spread in the kitchen; and a naked Wallace covers his privates with a candy box with the telling label, "May Contain Nuts". All of this is clever, but the real magic of the film comes from the fact that such mercurial facial expressions and fluid bodily movements can be made painstakingly from clay and wood. Somehow it all feels more vital and alive than anything from a computer. You can even see fingerprints on the models, a touch that curiously makes the characters even more magical. Even with no voice to call his own, Gromit is an amazing creation with just his stuffed-animal eyes and furrowed brow. There is an unfettered joy in watching the unerring visual invention show up with each new movie adventure, and I am happy to report that the newest installment is further proof of the magic they make out of their meticulously molded love and care.
summary: Joyful Visual Invention and Clever Storytelling Drive the Latest Park Concoction
Title: N/A

reviewText: What's not to like about two friends, man and dog, who establish a vegetable protection company?  Well-meaning Wallace and capable Grommit oversee and protect the vegetables being nursed for the "Giant Vegetable Competition" at Tottington Manor by inhabitants of some unnamed northern English town.  From the Vicar to Lady Tottington, they all treat their giant vegetables as if they were much-beloved children.  (Accurate, but loving bead drawn on "totty" English eccentrics by Nick Park, the director/creator of "W and G.")  The ever-inventive Wallace gets himself into trouble when, contrary to the sounder instincts of Grommit, he exchanges "thoughts" with a bunny - the cuddly enemies of the vegetable-set.  Well, one thing leads to another and the result is just good fun.Park has a deft and masterful way of evoking atmosphere and you would swear the clock had been turned back and were in Leeds or York just after the war.  It's really hard to believe that the characters are actually made of clay and that this is stop-action animation. (That is until you see the fingerprints of human molders on Grommit's face.)  The "W and G"s are masterpieces of the art and we thank Nick Park for this clever and very entertaining work.  "Best of show."
summary: Entertaining Romp
Title: N/A

reviewText: Those expecting a full-length "Wallace and Gromit" feature to preserve the goofy lighthearted quirkiness of W&G;'s genius-level shorts will be disappointed. But, not to worry. Though W&G; were forced to bow somewhat to cinematic formulas, "The Curse of the Were-Rabbit:" preserves more than enough of the original to be quite satisfactory.A quick take on the plot: Wallace and Gromit are in the pest control business. The "pests du jour" are garden-wrecking rabbits. But though our heroes do catch the critters, they can't bear to dispatch them. With their home overrun by rabbits, Wallace cooks up a typically hare-brained (!) scheme to take the bite out of the bunnies by brainwashing them to hate veggies. The plan backfires, of course, and the movie is on its way.The cast of characters is delightful - addle-brained plebian Wallace and his silent-though-brilliant dog friend Gromit; carrot-topped Lady Tottington, voiced by Helena Bonham Carter; gun-toting Victor Quartermaine (a play on his need for a toupée), sneeringly voiced by Ralph Fiennes, and a town full of panicky pastors and vegetable lovers of every size and shape.The filmmakers mined every monster and adventure movie cliché for this film -- from King Kong to Frankenstein to Indiana Jones. This will be great fun for those who enjoy deciphering film references, but it may induce a twinge or two in those who want their W&G; served up without reference to the outside world.From an animation perspective, the film is breathtaking. There are many, many scenes in which dozens of characters are animated simultaneously. The Rabbit Vac scene comes to mind - dozens of cute bunnies free-floating inside a huge vacuum chamber. To imagine this being done with hand-molded clay is mind-boggling.For all of its filmic improbability, though, the plot never strays too far from plausibility. When Grommet take to the skies in an airplane carnival ride, he doesn't fly as much as plummet, gaining altitude with the assistance of fortuitously-placed spiral ramps and jumps.Sadly, I am one of those spoilsports who can't get enough of the goofy innocence of the W&G; shorts. This film chips away at that with a few semi-crude visual jokes (of the "Look at the size of those melons!" variety) that I could have done without. Then, there is the whole were-rabbit thing, which could have been played as a comic over-reaction of the townsfolk, but is really given its full fright value. Still, the film did stay true to class boundaries (W&G; are British, naturally) and a potential love affair between member of different classes never fully materializes."Wallace and Gromit in the Curse of the Were-Rabbit" is not a film I'd necessarily want for my DVD collection, but I would like to see it again, if only to enjoy the superb craft that went into making it. Given time, I may even relax my need for W&G; purity and learn to enjoy it completely.
summary: An awesome achievement of the animator's art

reviewText: Devoted fans of the three original Wallace and Gromit short films (all three of which were nominated for and two of which were winners of Oscars) have long harbored a desire to see more from the gifted clay-animator Nick Park.CHICKEN RUN did not fulfill that desire.At long last, Park's original pair appear in a full-length feature, and CURSE OF THE WERE-RABBIT lives up to all of the Wallace and Gromit aficionados' high expectations. A highly entertaining picture for children, there is also plenty here for adults to enjoy as well. The humor is dry and British, but multi-layered. There is none of the terribly self-conscious attempts at hipness and desperate stabs at in-jokes that seem to so infect the Disney, Pixar, and Warner films of late. What remains is an intelligent film which is both highly funny, original, and timeless.It is my suspicion that most "Wallace and Gromit" fans could actually more accurately be described as "Gromit" fans, and I am no exception to this suspicion. Gromit is as expressionistic as ever in THE CURSE OF THE WERE-RABBIT, and can easily be considered one of the greatest of non-speaking characters in film today. We certainly hope that this is not the last time we see Gromit and the rest of this cast up on the big screen.Jeremy W. Forstadt
summary: Gromit lives!

reviewText: Wallace and Gromit are in for their biggest adventure yet. With the town biggest vegetable competion coming up, Wallace's and Gromit's rabbit away system is extremely popular. But when a mysterious rabbit is eating all of the vegetables, Wallace and Gromit must find out who did it. With the competion and the townspeople on their tails, they have a hare raising adventure ahead of them.Growing up with the shorts, I was suprised that Wallace and Gromit were going to hav a motion picture. They have had wildly popular adventures and are probably as loved as much as generations of children as Barney is. I rememeber laughing so hard at their antics that I couldn't stop. They have such a warm appeal and are some funny guys. Some of the fans were worried that the translation to the big screen wouldn't work. I have to say, it was like watching one of the shorts but only a hour longer.Nick Park's stop motion animation is wonderful. He amazed me at what he did with the characters and how he created situations with them. He used slapstick wonderfully and it fit the realm of the cartoon perfect. The cartoons have had some slapstick but this realy uses it to its potential. Also, along with the slapstick there was some pretty funny refrences that I got and probably some of the kids in the cinema that I was in didn't. That shows that Nick Park's cartoons can basically appeal to anybody and their mothers. Also, the characters of Wallace and Gromit are charming, charasmatic, and funny characters that have massive appeal. I like the way thet Nick Park didn't rely on gross humor(although, there were some parts that were funny with the gross humor). His humor shows that you can be good and clean and have a fun time.The only flaw of this film is, yet again, the stop motion animation. I know that it took the filmmakers a long time to make it and it was a long and stressful process. I commend them for that. But, the film was way too fantastic to be that short. They could've made it longer and make it more enjoyable. But, the finshed product didn't feal all that rushed and it was a great experience to watch it. I hope you have the same joy and experience that I had when you watch this movie.
summary: A carrot a day doesn't keep this rabbit away.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Curse of the Were-Rabbit is an 85 minute, full-length adventure with the short-feature claymation heroes Wallace and Gromit. Peter Sallis, now in his 80's, voices inventor Wallace who along with his slightly more intelligent dog Gromit, are a security-service keeping the town veggies safe from rabbits before the approaching vegetable contest. The pair meet Lady Tottington (Helena Bonham Carter), customer and love-interest for Wallace. Lady Tottington appreciates their humane methods, the Bun-Vac 6000, while the gun-toting Victor Quartermaine (Ralph Fiennes)does not. Before long an invention gos 'ORRIBLY WRONG and creates a giant were-rabbit which threatens to do more than just put Wallace and Gromit out of business.Nick Park, creator of Wallace and Gromit shorts, probably best known by mainstream audiences for "Chicken Run" and the "Gas commercials with talking car testimonals, does his best work here. The "Curse of the Were-Rabbit" spoofs the monster movie classics with lighting and camerawork so perfect, you'd swear some scenes were in black & white. In spite of it's G-rating Park throws in some cheeky "Benny Hill" moments aimed at older viewers, but nothing to take away from the family appeal of a film destined to be one of the best films ever to use the claymation medium.
summary: "5 carrots out of 5!!!... Two paws up!!!"

reviewText: One of the best and funniest movies I've seen in a long time!  Wait, that's exactly what I would have said if I had written a review of "The 40 Year Old Virgin".  But seriously this is a laugh out loud enjoyable film.I highly recommend you watch the short oscar nominated and winning earlier adventures of W & G.  This will introduce you better to the two main characters: Wallace- the cheese fetish and whacky inventor that often finds himself in some sort of crazy predictment, and Gromit his mute, very human like dog/sidekick, who always comes to his rescue.This highly creative and simple story will grab you almost immediately into this world of claymation.  This movie took over 5 years to make, but well worth the wait.Everything that the creators did previously in "Chicken Run", where I was hugely dissappointed, was made up in mere minutes in this film.  Perhaps it was due to the fact that the two main stars are extremely likeable and hilariously written, or in Gromit's case just facial expressions.The drawings and the quick, quirky and great dialouge keeps the pace going at warp speed.  Especially during the plane chase sequence late in the film.  With so much going on at once you feel like your seeing a James Bond/ Indiana Jones storyboard adventure.  Come to think about it, most of those movie are done in a very similar fashion.  Sometimes the entire move is done frame by frame, like a comic book story, especially the action scenes that are hand drawn for more visual effects.  Steven Speilberg has been doing this for decades.  Maybe that's why his movies are so amazing.This is one of the movies that works much better in theaters than on the small screen.  The visual effects and quick references to preivous Wallace and Gromit adventures are quickly displayed throughout.An added bonus is the quick short with the penguins from the Madagascar Movie.  So make sure you arrive on time for an extra fun treat.
summary: Laugh out loud hilarious!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a charming little British comedy of the sort that the Boulting Brothers and Ealing Studios used to turn out on a regular basis.  Fifty years ago, Alec Guinness or even the young Peter Sellers would have been Wallace, with Joan Greenwood as the Lady of the Manor and Terry Thomas as her scheming, gun-happy suitor. Crowds of wonderful character performers such as Ian Carmichael, Alistair Sim and Joyce Grenfell would have drifted in and out of the background from time to time, each contributing a brief but brilliant acting turn. This is a slow-moving, but wickedly smart school of comedy, not the seize-your-throat-and-drop-the-2000-pound-weight sort of thing associated with Monty Python, and very pleasing to see after too long an absence.Children will be lightly amused. Adults--or anyway, those who use their heads for more than stylish support of a reversed baseball cap--once they have adjusted to the rhythm of the film, will find it funny and very, very clever.Five stars.
summary: An Ealing Studios comedy in animated form
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of the funniest and cutest of all Wallace and Gromit features. I love Wallace and Gromit in everything, and this movie is one of their best. It is certainly the best film out at theatres right now, a much-needed tonic to the trash that floods theatres and the ghoulish nightmare visions of Tim Burton. Finally, here's a great Halloween film for old and young alike, with nary a flaw or unclever moment in sight. How do they make clay animation this good? I, being a former movie fanatic, appreciate the nod to the old Universal horror classics, which are almost as much fun as this. How can anyone not love the rabbit that turns into Wallace? Every sequence is brilliant and detailed, full of warm and humorous moments. I hope they make another Wallace and Gromit film soon--we need more of them! What's with all the complaints people? A big thanks to Nick Park and his terrific crew for bringing these lovable and creative characters to the big screen. Also check out the duo's other short films if you don't already own them like I do (their house is  like a dream come true for wannabe inventors!).
summary: How can anyone complain about a film this fun...

reviewText: Wallace (Sallis) is an inventor and Gromit is his dog.  Despite that, Gromit is the smarter of the two.  They run an animal removal service called Anti-Pesto.  They don't kill the pests, the capture them and remove them from the area in question.  This is especially important with the Lady Tottington's (Bonham-Carter) Giant Vegetable Contest coming up.  Things are looking good for all until a giant were-rabbit shows up to throw the small town into chaos.  Wallace and Gromit set out to capture it, while Victor Quartermaine (Fiennes) is set to kill it.  At the same time, they are competing for Lady Trottington's affections.Sound silly?  It is  a bit, but it is also highly entertaining.  The creaters of "Chicken Run" have brought Wallace and Gromit to the big screen in style.  The stop motion animation is so good that the silent Gromit's emotions can easily be read on his face in every scene.  The story is funny, and engaging.  This is a very good movie for the family that will be thoroughly enjoyed.
summary: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit
Title: N/A

reviewText: Is Nick Park really P.G. Wodehouse Jr.? "Wallace and Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit" really makes you wonder. I certainly can't be the only one to notice that Wallace is an older, balder, less financially privileged version of Bertie Wooster, or that Gromit is essentially Jeeves in a Snoopy suit. And it's hard to miss the Wodehousian precedents of such characters as idealistic Lady Tottington or that frightful cad and bounder Victor Quartermaine. Park and Wodehouse have other things in common as well: painstaking preparation (just as Wodehouse wrote hundreds of pages of outlines for each new story and novel, Park spent five years on "Curse of the Were-Rabbit," making sure every detail was just so) and a tender concern for our furry friends (Wodehouse, who left the bulk of his fortune to help homeless pets, would resoundingly approve of Wallace and Gromit's humane methods in protecting their neighbor's vegetable gardens from thundering herds of ravening bunnies). Obviously Wodehouse, the master of the written word, and Park, the master of stop-action animation, have as many differences as similarities. But who can deny that we get fundamentally the same pixilated pleasure from "Curse of the Were-Rabbit" as we do from "What Ho, Jeeves"? Certainly these two comic geniuses have lavished all their abundant talent on projects whose only aim was to please and entertain mass audiences, and in the bargain show them the way to a kind, gentle, humane, serenely English world. Surely Bertie and Wallace must be having tea together in some cozy parlor, while Jeeves and Gromit try to steer them away from the Stilton and toward the nice, healthy celery.
summary: What ho, Gromit!
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Nathan Andersen "Gadget lover and author of S...
reviewText: First, for the fans: this is not going to disappoint those who fell in love with the off-kilter humor and brilliant animation of the original three short films in the Wallace and Gromit series.  It is every bit as clever and inventive, does not pander to its audience, does not lose anything in coming to the big screen.  Far from it, this is the best of the bunch, that starts off well and continues to build comedic momentum as the story continues.  The grand scale of widescreen 35mm film allows the animators to push their inventiveness to new heights: the world they create seems every bit as detailed and real (even though obviously its own kind of real) -- maybe even more so -- as almost any "live action" film I have seen.Second, for the rest of you who have never heard of Wallace & Gromit, or who find uninteresting the idea of a daft middle class Brit who is, inexplicably, a remarkable inventor, and his even more clever but silent dog, you will still find yourself rolling in the aisles and smiling in spite of yourself at the wonderfully witty humor and the clever satire, and silly innuendoes of this film.  For overall enjoyment, this film can be compared with Shrek -- though I found myself laughing even harder and smiling even wider at this one.  Remarkably, though they are made of clay, the characters in this film seem to exhibit more character than the CGI animated creatures of Shrek (and certainly more feeling than most of the films you'll see at the local multiplex anyhow).  My wife, who was not very interested in seeing this film - and had only seen parts of "The Wrong Trousers" -- and had to be dragged along with me and my children ages 5 to 9, was laughing as loud or louder than anyone else in the theater and absolutely loved it.Gromit is the star of the show, and it is really fantastic the way in which the filmmakers are able to convey so much feeling on just his canine face without any dialogue.  Beyond that, the film manages simultaneously to be a novel and underivative but very funny story in its own right, while also making loads of sly and silly references to classic horror and film noir, and containing jokes that work at a number of levels (for parents and for their children).  This is one film that I won't mind watching with my children many times.
summary: Full of laughs, brilliantly animated, a very clever film that will not fade with time

reviewText: Wallace and Gromit: The Curse Of The Were-Rabbit is pleasant and cute for adults, suitable, fun, and funny for kids, and an absolute must for serious animation fans.The story is about an English inventor, Wallace, his faithful dog Gromit, and their pest control company, Anti-Pesto.  Everyone in their community is preparing for a giant vegetable festival, and depending on Wallace and Gromit to protect their vegetables from rabbits in the meantime.  Wallace invents a mind control machine, originally planning to aid his diet, but uses it on the rabbits to transfer his loathing of vegetables to them.  Unfortunately with extra lunar power energizing the machine, he accidently throws the wrong switch and creates a were-rabbit, that turns into a giant rabbit when the moon is full, ravaging the prize vegetables throughout the region.There's also plenty of comedy, just like the computer animated films like Madagascar, Ice Age, Finding Nemo, etc., enough to recommend it as a comedy for the whole family.  The retro-style Rube Goldberg contraptions Wallace invents are an added bonus.The animation here is done the old way, the hard way, the artistic way, with real clay models and puppets for each character, moved painstakingly by dedicated animators one frame at a time, often taking days to achieve a few seconds of usable film.  This is the way Willis O'Brien did King Kong, the way George Pal did his puppetoons like Tubby Tuba, and in the age of computer animation like Toy Story, it's rarely used anymore (with occasional exceptions to some extent like Tim Burton's Nightmare Before Christmas).  Feature-length comedies with this stop-action animation technique are very scarce; it's usually onely used for shorter films like Rudolph The Red Nosed Reindeer, Claymation, Puppetoons, etc., and for special effects in old sci-fi movies, which Ray Harryhausen mastered in the 1950s. The result is fun to watch in and of itself.
summary: Best stop-action animation comedy.

reviewText: Wallace and Gromit are back, in the Curse of the Were-Rabbit, and it was worth the wait.For those not familiar with the Wallace and Gromit franchise, it's a set of movie shorts, in which the characters are all portrayed in claymation. Wallace is the mild-mannered Englishman inventor and cheese-lover, and Gromit is his faithful dog. You get the sense that Gromit is sometimes the brighter of the two.Let me preview the plot without spoiling the movie. As the story opens, W&G; are running a garden-protection security outfit, protecting all the neighbours' gardens through a combination of a motion detection system and their own muscle. Rabbits are the big scourge of the neighbourhood, and W&G; are under some pressure to keep the neighborhood safe in advance of the upcoming fair, where the fruits of the gardeners' labours will be judged. W&G; have caught a large number of rabbits, but are loathe to kill them. So, what to do? Wallace's ingenious solution has unintended consequences for the neighborhood, the fair, and the duo.It's definitely a British production, in terms of characterization, setting, etc. The plasticene models appear more detailed in this film, relative to the previous productions. The film is a little more action-oriented, and there are visual allusions to various Hollywood movies, at least in my eyes: Frankenstein, Temple of Doom, Jaws, An American Werewolf in London (and thereby Thriller) all come to mind.A great movie, with thrills and laughs, for the entire family!
summary: W&G conquer the world!

reviewText: This was released in our local cinemas to coincide with'Wonka's Chocolate Factory', and the distance between their modes and their appeal was keenly felt. It really was a contrast say between homegrown, organic vegetables, and shrink-wrapped glamourous GM ones from the supermarket. Cheese enthusiast, and home inventor, Wallace cruises around with faithful hound Gromit pursuing an infestation of rabbits that are spoiling the local's vegie plots. He has on hand a rabbit vaccuum pump, a user friendly means of eradication, in sharp distinction with the aristocratic, Victor Qurtermaine's shotgun. There's an edgy surrealism to Wallace's invention which, as in experiments in earlier episodes, threatens to backfire. Verbal and sight gags are piled on top of each other and there is surely enough detail lavished here to repay many viewings.

reviewText: This movie has been so heaped with praise, I don't really feel I can add much.  I think the key thing to know about Wallace & Gromit is that this is a movie for people of all ages in the BEST sense of the word.  Sometimes when a movie is called a "family" movie, this means something you can safely take your kids to...you might not like it yourself, but at least you don't have to worry that they'll pick up on all sorts of bad ideas.  Sometimes a "family" film is synonymous with broad, silly slapstick that doesn't stick with you for longer than it takes to walk to the car afterwards:  "The Pacifier," "Cheaper By the Dozen," "Daddy Day Care."But to me, another kind of "family" fare is the movie like THE INCREDIBLES...which I love by the way, so don't take this the wrong way.  These films work on two levels...they have humor for the kids (broad slapstick, silly visuals, loud noises) and they have other humor for adults (subtle political digs, wry sarcasm, sly visual in-jokes)...stuff that most kids won't really catch.WALLACE & GROMIT is a rare treat in that 95% of the jokes will be enjoyed equally by young and old...on the same level!  When the evil hound Philip pauses in the middle of a fight scene to reveal that he's carrying a purse...that's a hysterically funny moment...and it's funny to all members of the audience on the same level.  You hear EVERYONE laughing together.  Yes, there are some subtle things that probably only older kids or adults will get, mostly involving being able to read signs, labels, etc., very quickly.  And there's one delightful joke about nuts that is funny for kids on one level, and is a mildy risqué joke on another.These movies are so gentle and cute and charming and funny in an almost completely non-mean-spirited way.  The villain (brilliantly voiced by Ralph Fiennes) is a bumbling idiot, but he's not out to rule the world or anything.  Mostly he wants to shoot some rabbits and get Wallace away from the woman he loves.  (Yet believe it or not, the movie has one of the most thrilling chase scenes in recent memory...it's funny and exciting at the same time, with hardly a word spoken...it's just brilliant physical comedy.)If you've never seen WALLACE & GROMMIT, go out and rent their three short films before you see this movie.  While having seen those is not required to enjoy this full-length effort, I would say that you'll enjoy it more having a bit of a background of these two great characters.  The CURSE OF THE WERE RABBIT is like the culmination of everything being worked on in the three short films.So the main point I would like to make is that if you're an adult thinking of taking the kids to something that's "good for them," just be prepared to enjoy it every bit as much as your kids...probably more.  And if you don't have kids to take...go anyway.  This movie is better than almost everything else playing in the multi-plex right now.  It's just SO funny and warm-hearted.  Usually, when I hear the quote "guaranteed to leave a smile on your face," I cringe...I'm pretty cynical and its hard to leave a smile on me.  I may smile during the film a lot, but WALLACE & GROMMIT had me smiling for a long time afterwards, as I remembered favorite bits and marveled again at the craftsmanship involved.(PS:  There is also a short film featuring the penguins from MADAGASCAR before the film.  It's very funny too, in a more violent, Looney-tunes sort of way.  Make sure you get to the theater in time to see it too.)(PPS: If your youngest children saw CHICKEN RUN, and didn't really enjoy it too much...this film is much broader in scope and will certainly please them more.  CHICKEN RUN was, I believe it's safe to say, geared to a little more sophisticated audience...a slightly more cynical one, perhaps.  While it is a VERY fine movie as well, I have to give a slightly bigger thumbs up for CURSE OF THE WERE-RABBIT...I laughed out loud a bit more, I think.)
summary: Thoroughly winning in every possible way!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Wallace and Gromit have finally found a niche to make good money - 'Anti Pesto' a humane pest control outfit.  Business is booming because the annual Giant Vegetable Competition is just days away and everyone is willing to protect their precious vegetables at any cost.The only problem with running the new business is what to do with all the rabbits that they catch.  It wouldn't be humane to kill them, so Wallace stores them in cages in the basement.  But then the lightbulb goes off - what if you could change the rabbits' behavior so that they no longer desire to eat vegetables?  It seems the perfect solution and the perfect opportunity to test Wallace's latest invention - a thought changing machine.While Wallace sends vibes to the captive bunnies encouraging them to dislike carrots and cauliflower, he accidentally flips the wrong switch and finds himself sharing thoughts with one very unfortunate rabbit.  Everything seems to have turned out all right, though, until a huge were-rabbit starts devouring every vegetable in sight.  It is up to Gromit to solve the mystery and restore Anti Pesto's good name before they lose all their customers and Wallace loses his chance with the lovely Lady Tarrington!This latest installment in the Wallace and Gromit series is cute and clever, as all of the Wallace and Gromit adventures are, but it just wasn't as cute and clever as the others.  There were big laughs in the movie, sure, but not as many of the little touches that cause you to giggle your way through the whole film.  Still, this is definitely a movie worth seeing - especially to see how Gromit, Wallace's dog, who never says a word, gets his master out of every predicament he puts himself in.  This movie is squeaky clean so you can take the kids and it is fun enough that the adults and the teens will enjoy it, too.
summary: Still Charming & Funny, But Not As Good As the Original Three Shorts

reviewText: This was a truly wonderful movie, made with wit and charm and excellent storytelling.  There's imagination and artistry enough to mesmerize anyone.But it wasn't nearly as good as Chicken Run, which I think is Park's best and most enduring work.  That film was aimed at teenagers and by extension at adults.  There was a real mortal threat..a ridiculous one, in the form of that chicken-pie-machine, but still a very serious cause.  And they were fighting for Freedom and their Future. It was a very solid film in the disguise of a children's story.Here there's only a giant vegi-competition, which isn't a real cause that I could relate to.  There was some sort of naive romance in the distance for poor Wallice.. it all seemed underdeveloped and aimed at 7-year olds, and not being 7 I felt only amusement and happiness at the fun on the screen when I would have like to be bowled over at a higher level.Nick Park is still a genius, but this has a limited scope and I guess I've set my expectations too high.
summary: Excellent - but it's no Chicken Run.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Kids ****Adults ***Wallace (Peter Sallis), an inventor, and his dog, Gromit, have just started a new business protecting the village's vegetable patches. The annual Large Vegetable Festival, hosted by Lady Tottington (Helena Bonham Carter), approaches and the town has a problem with rabbits eating all of the potential prize-winning stock. Wallace invents a large vacuum that removes the rabbits from their burrows in a humane way. This attracts the attention of the other exterminator in town, Victor Quartermaine (Ralph Fiennes), who would just as soon put a bullet between the cute little bunny's eyes. After the animals are captured, Wallace and Gromit house them in their basement. One night, Wallace decides that perhaps he can use another invention, a mind alterer, to get the rabbits to hate vegetables. He opens up the cellar door, allowing the moon in to help power the experiment, which takes a turn for the worse. And the Were-Rabbit is born."Wallace & Gromit in the Curse of the Were-Rabbit" is one of the cutest animated efforts to come along in some time. Creator Nick Park (the man behind "Chicken Run") took five years to create a full length feature, in Claymation, centered around his beloved characters."Curse of the Were-Rabbit" is a great film for kids. Because everything is created in clay it looks like a picture book come to life. Everything has a slightly surreal look and all of the colors are brighter. Also, all of the characters, especially the animals, appear to be stuffed animals. The soft, rounded edges of the clay helps everything appear like it would be equally at home in the pages of a toy catalog. All of this leads one to think of the pages of a picture book coming to life, everything looks like a pop-up picture book. The kids will love all of the characters and their unique look. The clay doesn't allow for a lot of fine detail, lips, teeth and eyes are big, hair is more of a statement, Park uses these elements to provide exaggerated caricatures of British stereotypes.The story is impressively cohesive and involving. It is very difficult for most animated films to come up with a single story that can hold the interest for 90 minutes. Most resort to combining a variety of shorter stories, tied together by the barest of plots, to make up a feature length story. "Were-Rabbit" doesn't fall into this trap; the story is interesting and involving and cohesive throughout. Not only is there the issue of the rabbits, but a love triangle, of sorts, develops between Wallace, Lady Tottington and Quartermaine. Gromit has a rivalry with Quartermaine's dog. The town villagers also panic in very funny ways, at times resembling the characters in an old "Frankenstein" film.What the story doesn't have is a lot of laughs. It is extremely cute and will keep the young kids engaged for many repeat viewings. But the film lacks an adult element that will also keep the adults tuned in. The film is missing the type of humor or subversive elements only adults can understand and appreciate something the best Disney, Pixar and Dreamworks animated films are usually overloaded with. The humor is very dry and very British and because of this, the film will probably not appeal to many adults.However, the film as a whole is definitely worthy of your attention. Anyone who is even remotely interested in animation should be required to watch this film and experience a fading form of animation. Kids will love the film and adults may appreciate some aspects of the film.
summary: Great for kids, adults may not love it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ever since watching the Wallace and Gromit short picture, "The Wrong Trousers" not long after it had won an Academy Award, I became a fan of this charming British duo.  For those who don't know, Wallace and Gromit are the creation of Nick Park-a brilliant British filmmaker who is best known in the U.S. for being the guy responsible for CHICKEN RUN (In fact, it's largely because of the success of CHICKEN RUN, that WALLACE AND GROMIT: THE CURSE OF THE WERE-RABBIT came to be). Wallace is an inventor who creates all kinds of crazy gadgets to do basic daily chores and Gromit is his dog.  Wallace loves cheese and likes to talk. Gromit doesn't like cheese as much as Wallace and never speaks.  Though Wallace is human, Gromit is the real brains in the duo.THE CURSE OF THE WERE-RABBIT has been in production for over five years. I'm pleased to say that the film was worth the wait. In this film, Wallace & Gromit are working at their latest occupation--operators of "Anit-Pesto" a pest and rodent ridance service. Unlike other pest control experts, Wallace & Gromit run an operation that gets rid of pests, but doesn't harm them. They are good at what they do and their business is booming as the Giant Vegetable Competition approaches. However, one night a pest strikes gardens all over the town. It causes a huge amount of problems for Wallace & Gromit. As the festivities draw even closer, the town thinks of totally closing down the competition espcecially as rumors about a giant were-rabbit begin to spread.  Soon the whole town is turned upside down and it is up to Wallace and Gromit to set things right.I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. The film does run a little slower than previous Wallace & Gromit films. However, this is a feature-length production and unlike the previous short films and such, THE CURSE OF THE WERE-RABBIT is Parker's tribute to the classic horror and sci-fi films of long ago. The previous Nick Park films closely mirrored action adventure type movies. Though THE CURSE OF THE WERE-RABBIT includes a lot of that, it's more of a tribute to some classic "scary" films (DRACULA, THE WOLFMAN, etc.).  The movie is filled with references and many of them will be totally glossed over and missed by those who just don't get it.  The film is margeted towards children, but will probably be appreciated even more by adult who are cabaple of picking up most of the references.  Just be sure to stay away from the fridge for awhile.
summary: Flashback to Classic Horror and Sci-Fi Movies.

reviewText: I'll admit that I was a bit worried during the first fifteen minutes or so, because those first fifteen minutes are dreadfully slow.However, once it got going, this was a rollicking good ride; it was essentially a triple-length version of one of the shorts that got the whole thing started in the early 90's, on the same level of quality as "The Wrong Trousers" but with a much larger scope.There are a few hints of a more adult theme, but they are very slight, and I think they did that because they recognized that the movie's largest audience is going to consist of those that watched the original shorts.It's one of a very small number of modern "comedies" that are truly comical.  This is well worth the outrageous cost of 21st-century moviegoing.
summary: Excellent.

reviewText: Clay animation at its best! The three W&G; shorts from a few years back are still among my favorite animations. They're all beautifully done clay animations, with wonderfully clever little gags in the background, the kind I keep noticing even no matter how many times I've seen them.This full length feature uphold the W&G; tradition. Wallace is the inept inventory, Gromit his faithful and long-suffering dog. This time, they've taken on security monitoring of prize vegetable gardens, with their remarkable assortment of gadgetry. And, of course, the clientele are wholly consumed by their passion for vegetable gardening - that is to say, slightly nuts, the lot of them.There's a sneering bad guy, too, with his bad-guy dog. He competes not only for the lady of Wallace's affection, but also for the bunnies that over-run the townspeople's precious gardens. Then it gets personal ...No, I won't give it away. It's amazing, goofy, exciting, and gently satirical, with references to every movie from King Kong and Lang's Metropolis to Jurassic Park. Violence is cartoony at worst, kid-safe and never to be taken seriously. This full-length film lacks some of the quiet charm of the earlier short pieces - the cheese thing, for example is a bit over-done, as are Totty's lipstick and coiffure. Still, it's worth seeing for anyone who loves W&G;, loves animation, or loves a good kid's film, with or without the kid.//wiredweird
summary: Wallace and Gromit, Full Length!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I will start this review by saying I am a huge Wallace & Gromit fan.  I own all of the past Wallace & Gromit films (as well as other Nick Park films).  Wallace & Gromit in the Wrong Trousers and A Close Shave are both genuis movies.  When I heard that they were coming to the big screen in their forth movie, I was excited, and based on what I've seen of Wallace and Gromit, I was expecting a lot more than most of the garbage that's been in the movie theatres lately.  Wallace and Gromit in the Curse of the Were Rabbit just added to the list of garbage movies...Wallace & Gromit started out with a short using the characters from Madagascar.  I thought Madagascar was a horrible movie, but I wasn't too worried about it because it was a short.  In the end, it turned out that it was more like a long.  The thing was probably 10-15 minutes long that I did not want to watch.  Why keep it so long?  Possible to squeeze some more money out of the Madagascar characters.  In Pixar movies, a short is always included, but Pixar's shorts are always new characters and never last more than 2 or 3 minutes.  Also with this short, it was centered around Christmas.  Wallace and Gromit was a Halloween movie.  It just didn't go.  They should have just left out this short and went straight into the curse of the Were-Rabbit.  That's what the Corpse Bride did (the other stop motion animation movie that came out a few weeks before.  It was a very short movie).The Curse of the Were Rabbit started, and I have to admit that it did have some witty eye candy, but it lacked an original story, new concepts, and careful animation.  For the original story part, in the previous W&G; movies, each story was brand new and original.  They were something that made you say Wow about how these concepts were thought up.  In the Curse of the Were-Rabbit, the story was based on giant veggies and Wallace and Gromit's pest control business, but everything else seemed to be based on old horror movies.  There was were-wolf inspirations, King Kong, Psycho, the Incredible Hulk, and a lot more.  I want to know why this was done instead of coming up with something new. In my opinion, it was an attempt to tone down the movie a bit intellectually to make people who don't know or get W&G; find this movie more appealing by copying other movies instead of making something new and original.  I also found that this movie lacked new concepts.  This sort of includes involving all of the old monster movies, as well as stuff surrounding Wallace and Gromit.  In each of the three previous Wallace and Gromit films, as well as the cracking contraptions shorts, Wallace always had a slew of new inventions.  In Curse of the Were-Rabbit, it seemed like there wasn't much new.  There was the brain wave switcher and the rabbit vaccume, but that was about it.  Also in the lack of new concepts, in the action scenes, the concepts seemed used.  Gromit flew an airplane.  Big deal.  Gromit flew a much more intense airplane scene in a Close Shave (the best and most intense animated sequence ever created in my opinion that wasn't CGI).  Another used concept was having Gromit's nemissis being a dog.  Anyone else remember Preston the cyber-dog?  I could go on about the used concepts for a while, but I'll move on to my next gripe which was the sloppy animation.The animation itself was perfectly filmed and smooth (unlike the Corpse Bride, which was jumpy at times), but the way that some of the characters were put together and animated was my problem.  The villan and Wallace's love interest for example.  Why did they look so cartoony?  Compared to the rest of the people in the movie, who looked human like, these two characters didn't fit.  Their lips, hair, and motions didn't fit with the typical Nick Park animation style.  To me, it seemed like they were made by a totally different animator.  The villan dog and all of the rabbits also seemed to be hastily made.  Compared to the supporting animals in A Close Shave, these animals looked like they came out of an episode of Gumby, and not Wallace and Gromit.  Again, I could go on for a while, but I won't...I still reccomend Wallace and Gromit fans to go see this movie, but don't get your hopes on.  The Curse of the Were-Rabbit isn't up to par with W&G;'s past high standards.  I just hope that this was W&G; first attempt at the big screen and isn't that great (like A Grand Day Out), and in the next big screen attempts, the films will get better and better.
summary: I had my hopes way to high and was disappointed...
